chapter.title: The University of Silence

para.emphasis: Zechariah said to the angel, “How can I be sure of this? For I am an old man, and my wife is old as well.” The angel answered him, “I am Gabriel, who stands in the presence of God, and I was sent to speak to you and to bring you this good news.”

chapter.para: Jesus was about to come to Israel, to a nation that by and large had forgotten God's promise to bring a deliverer. Or they had changed him into a deliverer in their own image: one who would deliver them from the Romans.
God needed to raise up a man who would help people to see the real Jesus.
But all men start out as little boys. So God's first task was to prepare a man, one in this culture of academic religion, to raise this little boy--to become John the Baptist.
John needed to be the sort of man who could hear God's voice and be a prophet to his people.
John needed a daddy who could hear God's voice and be a prophet to him first. He needed a family where he could be nurtured and could grow into the kind of man that God wanted for him to be.
There was one problem. The man who God had prepared to raise John the Baptist had given up believing that God could speak, that God could work miracles--at least miracles for him.
So God first confirmed through casting lots among the other priests that Zechariah was to serve him in the temple.
Many times when God wants to use us in some way, he begins by confirming this in an objective way through other people who love him.
But this wasn't enough for Zechariah.

Next, God sent Gabriel the angel to Zechariah. The appearance of the angel must have been magestic and awe-inspiring, because the Bible says that Zechariah was visibly shaken when he saw then angel and seized with fear.
Even this wasn't enough for Zechariah.
Then the angel delivered his message--that God was going to give Zechariah a son.
But even this wasn't enough.

para.emphasis: Zechariah said to the angel, “How can I be sure of this? For I am an old man, and my wife is old as well.” The angel answered him, “I am Gabriel, who stands in the presence of God, and I was sent to speak to you and to bring you this good news.”

chapter.para: Fortunately, God had a cure for Zechariah's unbelief:

para.emphasis: now, because you did not believe my words, which will be fulfilled in their time,61 you will be silent, unable to speak, until the day these things take place. (v20)

chapter.para: When Zechariah left the temple, he not only was unable to speak, but since people had to motion to him to communicate, it seems that he was also unable to hear.

What had been true of Zechariah spiritually was now true of him physically. He had been unable to hear the good news from the angel, and now he could not hear what anybody said. He had been unable to believe, and thus unable to speak with faith the prophesy the Lord had given him, and thus he was also unable to speak.
But as if this weren't enough, at this point, everybody else but Zechariah gets to hear the Lord speak and to prophesy his words.

Mary receives a visit from the angel, receives the word of the Lord and believes it. Next thing we know, Mary is visiting Elizabeth and before we know it both are filled with the Holy Spirit and are prophesying.
And Zechariah simply gets to watch it all happen but not receive any of it for himself!
How his heart must have yearned to have another chance to hear the angel's voice! How he must have desired to be able to speak with his own voice, "We are having a son, and his name will be John!"
But he couldn't. And so the desire to hear and to speak undoubtedly grew in his heart--until the 8th day after John had been born and God's word had been fulfilled.

That day, there was a commotion about what to name the child. All of the people in the world wanted to name him according to his earthly father's name. But at the right time, the writing tablet was given to Zechariah, and he wrote, "His name is John!"
And then Zechariah again heard God's voice, and delivered God's word in a beautiful prophesy to the people!
God had transformed Zechariah from one who was righteous before him, but whose faith was weak, into one who heard God's voice, spoke God's word, and obeyed with expectency.

Sometimes we, too, suffer from periods of dryness. Like Zechariah's, they may stem from unbelief, but that may not be the only reason. But frequently God is allowing these times of silence as a kind of university--to deepen our desire to pursue him above all else.
When we emerge from these times, God gives us a new revelation of himself, of the work he has for us to do. And God puts new words in our mouth: words of praise, adoration, and direction.
Because ultimately:

listitem.para: God wants us to have a love relationship with him, not just beliefs about him.
God wants to use us to raise up the spiritual children who will teach others to know God.
Just as Zechariah's family was how God raised the first "John the Baptist", family-style relationships are how we grow up to maturity in anything, including in our relationshp with God.

chapter.para: May God see fit to use us to raise up a new generation of "John the Baptists" to prepare the way of the Lord.
Because Jesus is coming again, and the world needs to be prepared for him.
